caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW TRIBUTE TO THE HON MR JUSTICE J N K TAYLOR
summary: This document is a tribute to Justice J. N. Kobina Taylor upon his retirement from the Ghanaian Supreme Court on 30 March 1990 at age 65, marking the end of 21 years on the bench and 31 years in legal service. Born in 1925 in Accra, Taylor rose from humble beginnings to become one of Ghana’s most respected jurists. His career spanned roles as Crown Counsel, Director of Public Prosecutions, Acting Attorney-General, High Court Judge, and Supreme Court Justice. Known for his fearless independence, intellectual rigor, and commitment to human rights, Taylor frequently delivered dissenting opinions that challenged state overreach and upheld individual liberties, as seen in cases like Kwakye v Attorney-General and Appiah v The Republic. He rejected outdated precedents when unjust, as in Nkrumah v Manu, and enriched Ghanaian jurisprudence, particularly in customary law (Billa v Salifu). The Ghana Bar Association honored him uniquely, citing his exceptional legal excellence, integrity, and contribution to the rule of law, while also calling for reforms to judicial tenure to protect independence. Taylor’s life and work exemplify a deep commitment to justice, fairness, and the development of Ghana’s legal system.
verdict: Honorary recognition of distinguished judicial service and contribution to Ghanaian law.
winningSide: Legal profession and public interest in judicial integrity
citations: Mensah v GFA (Supreme Court, 24 January 1989) [1989-90] GLRD 2
rationaleHighlights: Justice Taylor championed individual liberties and criticized oppressive state actions.
He rejected binding precedents when deemed legally unsound, showing intellectual independence.
His dissenting opinions in key cases emphasized fairness and constitutional rights.
He advocated for a culture of legality and respect for the rule of law.
The Ghana Bar Association honored him uniquely, citing exceptional legal distinction.
